comments.commentBody: Folks, this is about money.  The Second Mile charity did nothing about this because they didn't want to loose their funding.  The University did nothing about this because they didn't want to loose their funding.  Sick.

One side note that is also very disturbing, is that the janitors who witnessed one of the alleged incidents were so fearful for their jobs, that they didn't report it to the police. That by itself shows what an oppressive atmosphere was pervasive at the football facility. I'm sure Penn State is not alone in that sense.

What comes to mind when reading this is the young child in China who was hit by a truck and is ignored by people passing by for an hour as child lie bleeding in the street and eventually died( see youtube video). My reaction is that it could never happen in the USA... and yet , is this any different? Multiple people witness or are aware of a heinous act and do nothing knowing the perpetrator will do it again? I thought our morality was better than the Chinese who ignored the dieing child. Clearly the same ability to ignore the unthinkable exists not only within the population, but within people of responsibility and authority as well.

Conrad Murray killed MJ! Casey Anthony killed bay-bees! Molestation at a mediocre state university!  HORRORS! The bigger crime here is the media's easy 1-2-3 replacing of gossip and tabloid repeating over REPORTING.  None of us are responsible for Sandusky.  Give us news we can fight for.  Too bad Reagan removed ISSUES from journalism years ago!

But wait for the rest of the fallout:
1. the sicko has 6 adopted children. Has he abused them? We haven't heard yet. The odds are very high. And what of his wife?
2. Joe Paterno has the nerve to have a press conference scheduled for tomorrow and has already stated he will only answer questions about football. Even if we believe he did not know (impossible) he still thinks football is more important. That he could talk about anything else in light of these events is sick. If he has any morals (questionable) he will step down. If the Catholic Church is a precedent he won't - none of the priests' higher ups did either.They just paid settlements.
3. The grad assistant got a sweet little job just 2 years after "reporting" the incident he WITNESSED to Paterno and not the police. What did he compromise for a job at Penn State?
4. When did Paterno become a replacement for the police?

Those poor children not having anyone to protect them - they learned they meant nothing. We create our own monsters in this society. What will come of them? And what kind of abuse did Jerry Sandusky suffer as a child? There is more to this story. None of it will be good.

Penn State administration and Joe Paterno makes me sick. I hope the alumni have the good sence not to throw money at their alma mater. Unless it's for counseling.

If the Archbishop of Kansas is charged for not reporting and following up, so too must Paterno.  It's tiring to see one standard for one group and another for another group, or person(s).  Paterno knew; Paterno should have followed up.

I worked at a Penn State campus and it had been a nice feeling to share in Penn State Pride. But no more.

But really--Joe, you failed us, not to mention Graham Spanier, the smart guy in chief. After all, Joe studied law, for goodness sakes. How could they look the other way, for years???? They had years to get used to the idea that a buddy was a horror. Even if they had spoken up last year they probably wold have saved someone. What kind of mental compartment did they put their suspicions in, deep down and far away in their minds? How many boys suffered because they looked away and didn't want to know? Shame on them.

Can you imagine Sandusky's behavior being tolerated outside sports?
What would Penn State do about a married woman in its theater program who over a decade brought a series of teen boys to rehearsals and on trips to see Broadway shows?
Or a retired sciences professor who brought young boys or girls to do experiments in empty labs late at night or overnight field trips?
Would it be considered OK for an engineer to shower a child with gifts from tech firms, like computers and phones, as Sandusky did with merchandise provided by Nike?
Any of those ALONE would have raised red flags and swift attention.

This is stunning! To have this many ppl know what's been going on and nobody did a thing, is amazing. How many more lives were ruined because of these cowards? They should all be thrown in jail. and the "hands of Paterno" stance is transparent. God help them all. and for Sandusky? ha, he'll get his in jail.
No one who has been around a football enthusiast will be shocked by this. It's pretty much par for the course among this depraved gang of hoodlums.

I have to wonder just how twisted the Paterno cult of personality is in Happy Valley that, when a graduate assistant sees a child being raped, his first impulse is not to stop the attack or get the police, but to tell Joe Pa.

The Penn State President Graham B. Spanier needs to resign as well -- he was aware of the incident in 2002 and he initially came out supporting both Tim Curly and Gary Schultz -- saying that he had complete confidence in how both of them handled the allegations.

Penn State's moral responsibility is to the children.  What has the university done to help them?  Has it even cared to find out who they are?  How much of the University's endowment will be turned over to the boys who were raped?  Most of it should go to them.

Today's issue of Time Magazine rated the U.S. as the fourth least regulated economy in the world.  How many more subprime mortgage and credit delay swap engendered recessions do we need, or is it a full-blown depression the same people who got us here want now?  The Great Derpession, the S%L debacle, the crushing of the small farmer in America, and now this recession.  Perhaps deregulation is the means for making all of the middle class poor because it certainly did a job on hundreds of thousands of our life savings and retirement funds.  I used to laugh at the claim that Wall Street was rigged but I'm not amused anymore, not after hearing the Senate investigation of what Goldman-Sachs did with its own worst products when no one was guarding unsuspected investors against their deceitful and formerly illegal duplicity.
The janitors feared for their jobs. Another reason for unions and an end to 'at will' employment.

I am a Penn State alum who has contributed a modest amount of money over the years. I also have Penn State named as a significant beneficiary in my estate. All that just ended. If Penn State can pay legal fees for these people, they don't need my money. I don't know of a business who would pay legal fees just because they are employees. If Curley and Shultz didn't know what the grad assistant says he saw, then Joe Paterno is lying. One thing I don't think Joe does is lie.
I am happy the grad assistant reported the incident. I am unhappy that he did nothing to stop the assualt. If it is who has been named in reports, he is 6'5" and at least 35 years younger than Sandusky. He could not have feared for his safety. I guess the football program didn't teach the traits that are needed to protect those who can't protect themselves.
This tragedy is far worse than the Ohio State issues or maybe any other that has occurred in college football in recent years. The problems have the same root which is money. Directly and indirectly, the money raised by college football is obscene. Only when individuals in charge of these money machines respect their own moral preachings and legal obligations more than winning sporting events will we stop seeing behavior that embarasses Universities, their administrations, and probaly worst of all their students and alumni.

I am a current student at Penn State University-University Park. I would like to respond to many posts of former graduates who are now ashamed of Penn State and assume that current students feel the same. While this is an atrocious situation and one of the worst abuses of power that we have seen, shame in my University is not what I feel. I feel embarrassed by the actions of a select few people, who unarguably did the wrong thing. I don't think anyone can debate that their behavior was inexcusable and that they should be punished to the highest extent that the law allows. However, I will never feel shame when I think about Penn State. Here is a quote that is being passed around the current Penn State campus, which shows how we feel:

Penn State Football doesn't define us. We are so much more than that. We are the number one school in the country among recruiters from leading companies, according to the Wall Street Journal. We are a leading research institution accredited by the National Science Foundation. We are over 94,000 students across campuses, with alumni in every state and 87 foreign countries. We are the creators of the number one student-run philanthropy in the world, raising over $78 million for the Four Diamonds Fund since THON's creation in 1977. Don't forget how incredible this university is, and don't allow irresponsible oversight to destroy our reputation. For the Glory.

We will not feel shame. We will be proud and continue to support our great university. What these men did was reprehensible and evil. They do not represent Penn State. Fight on State.

Paterno likes to feel superior to what he called the "Barry Switzers of the world." Right now Barry Switzer is looking like the soul of rectitude.  Paterno Inc. has nurtured and cherished its putative high moral and academic standards in a sport rife with corruption. The Fall was inevitable. I had a lot of Paterno's kids in composition class. They were terrific kids--and I never got a note from The Coach. Some of these guys are probably thinking about those slaps on the butt they got from Sandusky after a great play.  Some may be throwing up.  The real tragedy is about the lives of those little kids that Sandusky raped.  The lives that he stole.  Coaches like to tell kids that when it gets desperate on the field, someone has to "step up"--as the cliche runs.  Who stepped up to save the the Second Mile kids? Not one guy in Paterno, Inc. made the play; Joe was content to hand off responsibility to someone else. The monster was allowed to roam the showers and molest little boys at will--even as the first word of his book ("Touched") clues us all. Paterno, an English major, should have taken Sandusky at his word.

In too many cases bad or poor teachers are in the eye of the beholder. I had a schoolmate who went on to become a professor of chemistry at a Big Ten school. We had the same hi school chemistry teacher. I thought she was terrible. She did not have the knowledge of the cosmos that I had from just reading books by people like Gamow. I met the class mate a few years ago at a reunion and said she had been a fine teacher as a chemist.

The conservatives will try to make the unions the cause of any kind of poor performance. But unions would not exist if were not for poor management. It is the only protection they have against arbitrary and capricious behavior. It is far to easy to become disliked by some manager if your view of life is different that theirs. It is characteristic of the majority of those who attain managerial status, to expect others to have the same values and outlook on life that they have. We all have acquaintances that we can meet and say hello to, but we would not socialize with. They can be very nice people, who are well respected by their friends, but we would not be compatible in a closer relationship.

Most teachers are competent and like anyone else who has trained for a career, have a desire to do the best job possible. But in today's culture, many of them are assigned students that are disruptive, are slow learners, have home lifes that do not promote even reasonable courtesy toward others, and in particular teachers, and who simply do not want to be in school.

And yet, the teachers to whom they these students are assigned, are evaluated on a test developed by people who never had to work with these student. If they are failing, the parents blame the teacher, if they need discipline, the managers demand better supervision by the teacher.

That is the way managers work, and that is why employees at the bottom of the pile, need a union to see that they are treated fairly.

You would think from hearing and reading some of the reactions - both those involved and the general public - that this was a petty crime:  report it as best you can and you're done. Short of murder (and some victims would say it's worse than death, because suffering lasts a lifetime), this is a MAJOR crime that needs to be reported and dealt with immediately. People have been sent to jail for much much less. It's a reflection on our society that horrible crimes by the powerful towards the most vulnerable is more likely than not to be handled with kid gloves.

The insider, old-boys network has tried to draw the wagons around itself, but that strategy has failed. Spanier, Paterno, Raykovitz (CEO at Second Mile), and others need at last to set the right example: Acknowledge wrongdoing and resign instead of hiding behind legalistic arguments. The university and the community might then move on from the sordid mess these old boys have allowed to fester at the expense of already-abused children.

I use to live in New York before moving to University Park. What I've seen here has been astonishing, sometimes even a bit creepy and, well, its almost impossible to truly convey.

People take their babies to pose with the Penn State Nittany Lion statue, to all the statues on campus, to tour the campus, to Penn State games. It's not just an outing or vacation-it's a ritual. People raise their children on Penn State, on blue and white, as if it were cereal or breast milk. Joe Paterno isn't just some coach to them, he's a deity. Penn State isn't just a school to most of the students here. I see it in their eyes, they've been bred to idolize everything Penn State.

This wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, if this school were the heaven many students have been raised to think it is. Obviously no campus is. It's exactly this upbringing that leads to students not speaking out, not standing up for themselves, not thinking for themselves, to allowing professors and administrators to have more authority than they should. Since I've been here I've seen some corrupt, distasteful, and sometimes criminal things committed by faculty and administrators.

This is a system unchecked and unregulated by outside parties (Penn State virtually owns PA, body mind and soul, especially soul!) with layers of issues. What most people here need most is a broader perspective. It's truly sad because that is exactly what one is suppose to gain when they go off to college.

It's just something to keep in mind, when you ask why this has been allowed to go on, or why the graduate assistant (who believe me was not a "man", few of them here are) did not speak up. I understand the people here now, none of this is right and I think there's soon to be a broader sentiment of self betrayal.

One would think that if Joe Paterno had any moral values whatsoever (other than winning football games, which I don't really count as a moral value), he would have reported what he knew immediately and been so upset by what he knew that he would have personally assumed a role in pushing the criminal investigation forward IMMEDIATEWLY and not stopped pressing the matter forward until the professional police brought charges (or else found that the graduate student lied and Sandusky was innocent). After all, the rapes of children occurred on his turf and by a man working with him.  So he just turned a blind eye and went back to watching game tapes?  Did he think that what was good enough action for Catholic bishops was good enough for him?  Come on now.  Have we no moral values left in this country?

I confess that I am an attorney.  Here are just a sample of my deposition questions for Joe Paterno:  1) After hearing about the incident in the shower, tell me all the actions that  you took to ensure that the indicent was reported to law enforcement?  2) OK Coach, after you reported the incident to the athletic director, did you ever follow up in any way to ensure that the child victim was safe? 3) Tell me what, if anyting, prevented you from calling the police to report the incident?  Those three questions are just a few that I would have for Coach Paterno.  He may have met the university and legal requirements for reporting a situation to his supervisor, but he did nothing to follow up or make sure that a child hadn't been abused.  Mark my words, Coach Paterno will end up looking worse in all of this.

As a member of academia, what most troubles me is that incident feels like a story of inner-city anomie or high school groupthink, where bystanders witness a horrific crime but no one calls the police.  This time, it's my community, a community of college-educated individuals committed to higher education that has betrayed the very core of what we are supposed to stand for:  ethics before profit and personal prestige.  And when the president of Penn State expresses "unconditional support" for those members of his staff who kept silent, I feel like I've been hurled back to the 1950s ol' boy network.
